author: Harvey Fialkov
title: Florida Panthers send top draft pick Lawson Crouse to junior club
text:
In a surprising roster move Monday the Panthers decided to send teenage forward Lawson Crouse, the team's first-round pick in June's draft, back to his junior team in the Ontario Hockey League rather than give him the NHL-allowed nine game audition.
The Panthers also placed defenseman Dylan Olsen and forward Garrett Wilson on waivers. If both clear waivers by noon on Tuesday, they will be assigned to the Panthers' AHL affiliate in Portland, Maine. Their exodus could mean that veteran forward Martin Havlat, who's in camp on a professional tryout basis, has a chance to make the final 23-man roster, which is due at 5 p.m. Tuesday.
"It's never an easy decision. We're thinking big term," Tallon said of Crouse. "We felt it was more beneficial to play lots of minutes in junior and play in the World Junior [Championship] and have some success opposed to playing every other night on the third or fourth line.
"He's very close, but long term it was a benefit for him to … play with his peers and get some confidence that way and be the No. 1 guy on his team."
Tallon said the overall team depth as well as the stunning emergence of rookie forward Connor Brickley led to his decisions involving Wilson and Crouse.
"[Brickley] earned a job. He had a great camp and it started in rookie camp," Tallon said. "He's been terrific every day in practice and in games. It's a full body of work.

Brickley, 23, who scored 23 goals in the AHL last season, scored three goals in three rookie games and then added two more in the preseason while issuing bone-jarring checks on a regular basis. Tallon added that Brickley's fourth-line partner, rookie wing Quinton Howden, 23, also made the team because of his "speed and versatility."
Crouse, who had one assist and two shots on goal in three preseason games, tweeted out his reaction to the decision: "Had an amazing time with @FlaPanthers. Excited to get things going with the @KingstonFronts again."

The 6-foot-4, 215-pound Crouse will not follow the route of the Panthers last two 18-year-old first round picks — Aaron Ekblad and Aleksander Barkov — who made a seamless leap into the NHL four months after being drafted. Instead, he hopes to mimic the career path of Jonathan Huberdeau, who Tallon sent back to juniors only to see him win the Calder Trophy the following season.
"It certainly helped him," Tallon said of Huberdeau.
Crouse has been projected to be a top-six forward, and the Panthers only had one slot for him on a crowded, defensive-oriented fourth line that includes veterans Shawn Thornton and Derek MacKenzie.
Crouse, who scored 29 goals for the Frontenacs last season, was given an eight-game suspension for a head hit on North Bay's Marcus McIvor in the final game of the regular season. He will only have to serve half of that if he reports before Wednesday's game.
Tallon said that negotiations with Havlat's agent, Allan Walsh, were ongoing, and that he was, "hopeful," to get a contract done. But he also wasn't sure where Havlat — who in 14 years has tallied 241 goals but only 32 over his last four injury-plagued seasons — would fit.
"We're trying to find the right place for Marty," Tallon said. "We don't want to sign him and [have him] sit in the press box."
